awd_titl_txt: Systems of Lines: Applications of Algebraic Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award supports a mathematical research workshop entitled "Systems of Lines: Applications of Algebraic Combinatorics" to be held at Worcester Polytechnic Institute from August 10, 2015 to August 14, 2015. This workshop will bring together experts from around the world who study three subjects that are not obviously related but have deep connections between them. The organizers aim to foster cross-collaboration among mathematicians, computer scientists and physicists in order to identify common problems, tools and techniques among seemingly disparate applications of mathematics. Experts in algebraic combinatorics apply tools from algebra, graph theory and optimization to study error-correcting codes, spherical codes and highly regular designs for use in statistics and computer science. Quantum information theorists face problems of measuring and (approximately) replicating finite-dimensional quantum systems in their work on quantum algorithms, quantum cryptography and quantum state tomography. Signal processing experts employ compressive sensing to efficiently reconstruct a sparse signal through undersampling in a carefully designed manner. Data scientists now use ideas from compressive sensing for dimension reduction and the efficient handling of very large data sets. The URL for this workshop is http://users.wpi.edu/~martin/MEETINGS/WPILinesWorkshop.html

Beginning with the breakthrough work of Candes, Tao and Donoho in 2004, significant advances have been made over the past decade or so in the reconstruction of sparse signals while sampling below the Nyquist-Shannon limit. Beyond signal processing applications such as MRI, this theory has found new utility in the handling of big data. Matrices with the restricted isometry property (RIP) and random projections now enable effective dimension reduction which greatly enhances our ability to make useful inferences from large-scale data sets. Meanwhile, systems of lines play an important role in quantum information theory where mutually unbiased bases (MUBs) and symmetric informationally complete positive operator-valued measures (SIC-POVMs) promise to provide optimal measurements for finite-dimensional quantum states. Unfortunately, very little is known about how to construct these objects. All of these applications can be couched in the language of algebraic combinatorics where spherical codes and Grassmannian packings naturally arise in the theory of association schemes, in algebraic coding theory and the study of graph eigenvalues. By bringing people together from compressive sensing, quantum information theory, and algebraic combinatorics, this workshop will enable the application of tools and results from each area to the other and help identify the outstanding problems common to all three subdisciplines.

Overview

We report on a one-week workshop on combinatorics and its applications held at Worcester Polytechnic Institute during the week of August 10-14, 2015. The workshop successfully brought together experts and students from three research communities: compressed sensing, quantum information theory, and combinatorics.

 More specifically, the topics of focus were combinatorial tools for the construction and analysis of systems of lines in real and complex vector spaces as well as applications to data analysis and quantum information theory. These emerging and rapidly developing areas of application both employ techniques from algebra and discrete mathematics. In data analysis, the field of compressive sensing is concerned with construction, use, and analysis of transformations which reduce the dimension of a specially structured data set without unduly distorting the information it contains. In quantum information science, researchers utilize highly structured sets of lines for measurements of finite-dimensional quantum systems. These play essential roles in quantum cryptography and quantum state tomography, for example.

 As planning progressed, it became natural to broaden the scope strategically, both in order to provide context for the problems involving lines and as a way to keep a pulse on the latest results in these three areas beyond those involving lines. Applications to compressed sensing (e.g., the deterministic construction of matrices with the RIP property) and quantum information theory (e.g., the construction and existence of mutually unbiased bases) include numerous open problems which are notoriously difficult and essentially combinatorial in nature. This was the first meeting of its kind to bring together experts from all three areas in an intensive, focused workshop to discuss these problems and the tools available for their eventual solution. We were fortunate to attract top researchers in combinatorics who could explain the body of mathematics relevant to these problems and, at the same time, attract leading practitioners from these applied areas who presented the state of the art in each discipline.

 

Participants

The meeting attracted 47 participants, including 13 students, 9 postdocs/new PhDs, and 25 faculty/retired. We had 10 females and 37 males; three members of under-represented minorities; 32 coming from places inside the US, and 15 traveling from other countries. 

 

Scientific Program

The meeting consisted of 30 talks given over the course of five days.

As anchors, leaders were selected from each of the three areas: Duarte, Romberg and Waldron for compressed sensing; Flammia, Grassl and Appleby for quantum information theory; Barg, Tanaka and Wilson for algebraic combinatorics. We were pleased to have additional contributions from established leaders in combinatorics such as Paul Terwilliger and Seth Chaiken. And talks on quantum walks by Tino Tamon and Ada Chan provided an additional connective theme.

We were delighted to have talks of very high quality delivered by graduate students and postdocs in the three thematic areas of the meeting. To accommodate as many young participants as possible in the scientific program, we expanded the scientific scope of the meeting and this served to enrich the program with both breadth and depth. 

 

Budget

The NSF grant of $25,000 was spent entirely on participant support: flights (US-flagged carriers), Worcester Airport Limo, hotel rooms, food, other transportation. The NSF grant covered coffee breaks while supplementary funds from WPI covered the conference banquet on Thursday evening. 

 Impact

 The workshop was well-received and we were fortunate to find significant cross-disciplinary discussion and cross-fertilization between the three groups. We received many comments from participants about how the meeting helped them in their career. 

 

We list a few further benefits of the meeting:

 

  •  Nearly half the registered workshop participants (and the majority of non-registered WPI attendees) were students and postdocs. A meeting of this sort has a variety of positive impacts on early-career researchers such as these. Such impacts include: exposure to theory and application in an interdisciplinary meeting; exposure to world- class researchers; networking with faculty and other graduate students; advice and feedback on current research projects and thesis directions.
  • WPI had a faculty position open in Fall 2015 and the workshop provided us an early glimpse at some top postdocs who might be candidates. Over a half-dozen workshop participants applied for the position.
  • Numerous graduate students were inspired by the wealth of applications discussed at the workshop and several advisors remarked on the positive benefits that resulted as they train PhD students who attended.
  • WPI faculty and students from several departments attended and this initial interaction has continued to generate interdisciplinary discussions on campus.
  • A permanent web page has been established which contains the slides of most of the talks and a full record of the meeting: http://users.wpi.edu/~martin/MEETINGS/ WPILinesWorkshop.html This site will be used to provide links to papers that emerge from the participants as they relate to the workshop goals.

In summary, this federally funded initiative effectively brought together an interdisciplinary group attacking important problems of current interest and activity.
